title: 108_s2211
content: The Act may be cited as the "Abandoned Mine Land Reclamation Reform Act of 2004" and includes amendments to the Surface Mining Act. Amendments to Section 401 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 involve redesignating paragraphs and adjusting sentences for achieving the purposes of transfers under section 402(h). Additionally, Section 712(b) is amended by changing a reference from section 401(c)(11) to section 401(c)(9). Amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes to subsections regarding numbers and grants, with adjustments made to ensure compliance with the law. Amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes to subsections regarding numbers and grants, with adjustments made to ensure compliance with the law. In subsection (g)(3), adjustments are made to ensure compliance with priorities set forth in section 403(a) until certification is made under section 411(a). In subsection (g)(5), changes are made to funding allocations. Amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes to funding allocations under subsection (g)(5). States with approved abandoned mine reclamation programs may retain up to 10 percent of annual grants under certain conditions. The amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 allow for funds to be deposited into an acid mine drainage abatement and treatment fund established under State law. These funds are used for the abatement and treatment of acid mine drainage in qualified hydrologic units affected by coal mining practices. A qualified hydrologic unit is defined as an area where water quality has been significantly impacted by acid mine drainage from coal mining practices, adversely affecting biological resources. The amendments allow states to use funds from grants for reclamation of eligible lands and waters affected by acid mine drainage, in conjunction with other reclamation projects. The amendments allow states to use grants for reclamation projects under section 403(a). The Secretary must ensure grants of at least $2,000,000 annually to each State and Indian tribe. Additionally, the Secretary shall make transfers to the United Mine. The Secretary is required to transfer funds to various mine worker benefit plans based on estimated interest earnings. The total transfer amount is limited to the estimated expenditures for the fiscal year. The Secretary transfers funds to mine worker benefit plans based on estimated earnings, limited to expenditures for the fiscal year. The transfer includes amounts for health benefit premiums, benefits under the 1992 Plan, and the multiemployer health benefit plan established after July 20, 1992. The Secretary adjusts fund transfers to mine worker benefit plans based on estimated earnings for the fiscal year, including health benefit premiums and benefits under the 1992 Plan. Transfers are made only if actuarial projections provided by trustees support the decision. The Secretary determines fund availability for transfers to mine worker benefit plans based on actuarial projections. Transfers are subject to contribution rates not lower than those in effect at the time of enactment. Amendments to Section 403 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 are made regarding health and welfare provisions. In Section 403 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977, amendments are made to replace "health and general welfare" with "health and safety", adjust punctuation, and remove paragraphs (4) and (5). Subsection (b) is modified to address water supply restoration, and subsection (c) requires approval from the Secretary for amendments. Section 406(h) is amended to replace "Soil Conservation Service" with "Natural Resources Conservation Service". In Section 406 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977, amendments include changing "Soil Conservation Service" to "Natural Resources Conservation Service" and authorizing appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture. Section 408 is amended by removing a reference to surface ownership prior to May 2, 1977, and Section 411 is amended to include additional subsections. The Secretary may certify on behalf of a State or Indian tribe if all reclamation projects for eligible lands have been completed. Notice and public comment are required. Additionally, a State share is designated from funds under the Mineral Leasing Act for certified States. The Secretary shall pay qualified States an amount equal to the unappropriated amount allocated under section 402(g)(1)(A) for public domain lands available for leasing under the Mineral Leasing Act. Payments will be made in the same manner as under section 35 of the Mineral Leasing Act. The amount allocated to a State under section 402(g)(1)(A) as a result of a payment shall be reallocated for grants under section 402(g)(5). Section 510(e) of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to extend the limitation on the prohibition on permit issuance from "2004" to "2019". SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS TITLE. Transition Rules for the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 allow for the availability of allocated amounts for transfers in fiscal year 2004 and beyond. Interest credited to the fund established by the Act can be transferred to the Combined Benefit Fund as amended by this Act. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 allows for the transfer of allocated amounts to the Combined Fund to pay any deficit in net assets. The Secretary of the Interior must review additions to the inventory to ensure they reflect eligible lands and waters meeting specified priorities. Any lands or waters included in the inventory must meet specified priorities and criteria. Those that no longer meet the criteria will be removed from the inventory.
